subject: Re: REQ: Pro side of "use inner classes to test  private stuff"
msgSnippet: ... That s my approach.  Jury-rig it until you can get some real tests in. Then remove the rigging. I have yet to be convinced that under normal conditions
messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Ilja Preuss" <preuss@d...> wrote:
> Alain Ravet wrote:
>
> > Hard to say without an example, but in such a case, I would simply
> > change the visibility of the method from private to package
> > (in java). As I put the tests in the same package, but in another
> > source tree, that would do the trick.
> >
> > Should I have to make its "unpublished" quality more obvious, I'd
> > add a big red (html) "FOR TEST ONLY - DON'T USE" in the javadoc of
> > the method.
>
> Reasonable strategy. In the face of the tools I currently use, I'd
> probably think about alternatively deprecating it (in Eclipse, use of
> a deprecated method can be made very obvious, whereas I rather seldom
> take a look into javadoc).

That's my approach. Jury-rig it until you can get some real tests in.
Then remove the rigging.

I have yet to be convinced that "under normal conditions" you ever
need or want to test private stuff.. things that are private are
implementation details.. and as such not part of the behaviour of the
class.

Dave
